intro.para: In this chapter we introduce two fundamental operations on vectors, and learn how to use them:

li.para: The first operation is quite intuitive: the length or norm of a vector \Vect{x} is just the length of any arrow representing \Vect{x}. If \Vect{x}= (x_1,\dots, x_n), then the norm of \Vect{x} is

The norm operation has
algebraic properties
See the statement of the algebraic properties of the norm operation.
which match what one would expect of ‘length of a vector’.

The second operation is the ‘dot product’. It receives as input two vectors \Vect{x} and \Vect{y}. It delivers a
number, denoted \DotPr{ \Vect{x} }{ \Vect{y} }
See how the dot product is computed.
. The way the dot product is
computed
See how the dot product is computed.
conveys nothing of its meaning. It is, therefore, perhaps a bit surprising, that the dot product is a very useful and versatile operation.

This usefulness and versatility comes from its
geometric properties
Preview the geometric properties of the dot product.
. They tell us about the relationship between norm and dot product: \Abs{ \Vect{x} }^2 = \DotPr{ \Vect{x} }{ \Vect{x} }, and the angle between two vectors. In particular, we obtain a very convenient test for when two vectors are perpendicular.

We use the dot product to construct the
orthogonal projection of a vector onto a line

.

hyperspaces

distance
